stem: Click to highlight the findings that require immediate notification of the healthcare provider.
passage: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with Aortic Dissection (Tearing Pain). The nurse notes [sudden onset of severe chest pain described as tearing] radiating to the back, [diaphoresis], and [unequal radial pulses]. The vital signs show a [BP 90/60] on the right arm and [140/90] on the left arm.
correctSpans: sudden onset of severe chest pain described as tearing

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 S: Mr. Johnson, 68-year-old male, arrived via ambulance complaining of sudden, severe chest pain.
07:01 B: History of hypertension, currently managed with lisinopril. No known allergies.
07:02 A: Patient reports pain as 10/10, described as 'tearing' sensation radiating to his back. Appears anxious and diaphoretic. Noted unequal radial pulses; weaker on the right. BP right arm 90/60, left arm 140/90, HR 110, RR 24, SpO2 96% on room air. ECG in progress. 
07:03 R: Aortic dissection suspected due to presentation and vital sign discrepancies. Requesting immediate physician evaluation and orders for stat CT angiography and pain management. Consider labetalol IV for blood pressure control. Monitoring vital signs closely.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
SystemFinding
CardiovascularTachycardia, unequal radial pulses (weaker on the right), significant blood pressure difference between arms.
RespiratoryTachypnea, clear lung sounds.
NeurologicalAlert and oriented x3.
IntegumentaryDiaphoretic, pale.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Continuous cardiac monitoring
  • Oxygen via nasal cannula at 2 L/min
  • Insert two large-bore IVs
  • Stat CT angiography of the chest and abdomen
  • Administer morphine IV for pain (per physician order)
  • Administer labetalol IV for blood pressure control (per physician order)

rationale.correct: The sudden onset of severe, tearing chest pain, unequal radial pulses, and significant blood pressure discrepancy between arms are critical indicators of aortic dissection. These findings warrant immediate notification of the healthcare provider for prompt intervention.
rationale.incorrect: Diaphoresis, while concerning, is a non-specific finding that could be related to pain, anxiety, or other conditions. It does not directly indicate the severity or specific nature of aortic dissection as clearly as the other options.

answerBreakdown.label: sudden onset of severe chest pain described as tearing
answerBreakdown.content: This is the hallmark symptom of aortic dissection. The tearing sensation indicates a separation of the layers of the aorta, requiring immediate intervention.

answerBreakdown.label: diaphoresis
answerBreakdown.content: Diaphoresis is a non-specific sign of distress and can be caused by various conditions. While important to note, it is not as critical as the other findings in diagnosing aortic dissection.

answerBreakdown.label: unequal radial pulses
answerBreakdown.content: Unequal radial pulses suggest compromised blood flow due to the dissection, which can affect the arteries branching off the aorta. This is a critical finding that necessitates immediate medical attention.

answerBreakdown.label: BP 90/60
answerBreakdown.content: Hypotension in the context of suspected aortic dissection is a grave sign, indicating potential rupture or compromise of the aortic wall, leading to decreased cardiac output and perfusion. This requires immediate intervention to stabilize the patient.
While elevated, this BP reading alone does not necessitate immediate notification in the context of suspected aortic dissection. The disparity between arms is more concerning.

clinicalPearls: Aortic dissection presents with sudden, severe chest or back pain described as 'tearing' or 'ripping'.
Unequal blood pressures in the arms and diminished or absent pulses are common findings.
Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent life-threatening complications such as aortic rupture or stroke.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting diaphoresis because it is a sign of distress. While important, it is not specific to aortic dissection.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the specific symptoms and signs that are most indicative of aortic dissection, such as tearing chest pain, unequal pulses, and blood pressure discrepancies.

mnemonic.title: TEA for Aortic Dissection
mnemonic.expansion: T - Tearing chest pain, E - Unequal pulses/BP, A - Aortic dissection
